bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 91 (Tuesday, June 9, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. RYAN of Wisconsin:H.R. 2688.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 1 of the United StatesConstitution, to ``provide for the common Defence and generalWelfare of the United States.''[Page H4002]

item.title: A bill to block any action from being taken to finalize or give effect to a certain proposed rule governing the Federal child support enforcement program.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

item.name: Department of Health and Human Services

summary.text: This bill prohibits the Department of Health and Human Services from taking any action to finalize, implement, enforce, or otherwise give effect to the proposed rule entitled "Flexibility, Efficiency, and Modernization in Child Support Enforcement Programs" or any proposal set forth in the proposed rule.

bill.title: To block any action from being taken to finalize or give effect to a certain proposed rule governing the Federal child support enforcement program.

item.title: To block any action from being taken to finalize or give effect to a certain proposed rule governing the Federal child support enforcement program.
To block any action from being taken to finalize or give effect to a certain proposed rule governing the Federal child support enforcement program.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
